facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1275 to 1277 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1275 to 1277 of 1970.  From the Judgment Order dated the 2nd May, 1969 of the Madras High

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment of Madras High Court dated 2nd May 1969 in T.C. No. 41 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment Order dated the 2nd May, 1969 of the Madras High Court in T.C. No. 41 of 1966.  T. Desai, for the appellant, Hardyal Hardy and

facts.text: Madras High Court answered question under section 66 of Indian Income-tax Act 1922 against assessee and in favour of revenue for assessment years 1955-56, 1956-57, 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the Madras High Court whereby the High Court answered the following question referred to it under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 hereinafter referred to as the Act in respect of assessment years 1955-56, 1956-57 and 1957-58 against the assessee appellant and in favour of the revenue

facts.text: Question referred: Whether declaration filed by assessee under section 17(1) in respect of assessment year 1958-59 was operative for reassessments of previous years ending 31-12-1954, 31-12-1955, 31-12-1956 corresponding to AY 1955-56, 1956-57, 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the declaration filed by the assessee under section 17(1) in respect of the assessment year 1958-59 was operative in relation to the reassessments in respect of the previous years ending on 31-12-1954, 31-12-1955 and 31-12-1956 corresponding to the assessment years 1955-56, 1956-57 and 1957-58

facts.text: Assessee was studying abroad during the relevant period.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee during the relevant period was studying abroad. He derived income during that period by way of dividend on shares and interest from deposits.

facts.text: Assessee derived income by way of dividend on shares and interest from deposits during relevant period.

anchor.surface_text: He derived income during that period by way of dividend on shares and interest from deposits. The original assessments for the relevant years were completed on January 31, 1956, December 27, 1956 and February 28, 1958.

facts.text: Original assessment for AY 1955-56 completed on January 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The original assessments for the relevant years were completed on January 31, 1956, December 27, 1956 and February 28, 1958. The residential status adopted in those years was resident and ordinarily resident person.

facts.text: Original assessment for AY 1956-57 completed on December 27, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The original assessments for the relevant years were completed on January 31, 1956, December 27, 1956 and February 28, 1958. The residential status adopted in those years was resident and ordinarily resident person.

facts.text: Original assessment for AY 1957-58 completed on February 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The original assessments for the relevant years were completed on January 31, 1956, December 27, 1956 and February 28, 1958. The residential status adopted in those years was resident and ordinarily resident person.

facts.text: Residential status in original assessments was resident and ordinarily resident.

anchor.surface_text: The residential status adopted in those years was resident and ordinarily resident person. Income-tax and supertax were calculated at the rates applicable on the total income.

facts.text: Assessee filed declaration under section 17(1) on March 24, 1959 during assessment proceedings for AY 1958-59 claiming rates appropriate to total world income.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1958-59, corresponding to the year ending on December 31, 1957, the assessee filed a declaration under section 17(1) of the Act on March 24, 1959 claiming to be assessed at rates appropriate to the total world income.

facts.text: AY 1958-59 assessment completed on March 23, 1960 in status of non-resident; application under s.17(1) rejected.

anchor.surface_text: This assessment was completed on March 23, 1960 in the status of a non-resident. The application under section 17(1) was rejected.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer found assessee was non-resident in previous years ending December 31, 1954 to 1956.

anchor.surface_text: As the income-tax officer found that the assessee was a non-resident in the three previous years ending on December 31, 1954 to December 31, 1956 and his total income had been assessed to income-tax at the normal rates

facts.text: Income-tax Officer initiated action under section 34 to reopen assessments for AY 1955-56, 1956-57, 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: and further as he had failed to make the requisite declaration under section 17(1) within the requisite time, the income-tax officer formed the view that the earlier assessments had been made at a lower rate. Action under section 34 of the Act was accordingly taken by the income-tax officer

facts.text: Reassessments for three years completed under section 23(3) read with section 34; status non-resident; declaration rejected; taxed at maximum rates.

anchor.surface_text: and assessments for the above mentioned three years were reopened and completed under section 23(3) read with section 34 of the Act. The status of the assessee was treated as that of a non-resident. The assessee's declaration under section 17(1), which he had made in the course of assessment proceedings for the assessment year 1958-59, was rejected and ignored and his total income was brought to tax at the maximum rates.

facts.text: Assessee requested in reassessment proceedings that income be taxed at rates appropriate to world income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee in the course of the proceedings for reassessment requested that the income during the three years in question should be taxed at rates appropriate to his world income.

facts.text: Assessee contended omission to file declaration earlier due to inadvertence and ignorance.

anchor.surface_text: According to the assessee, the omission on his part to make the declaration earlier under section 17(1) was due to inadvertence and ignorance.

facts.text: Assessee contended that since assessments reopened, they are deemed pending, so 1958-59 declaration applies.

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that as the assessments were being reopened and were thus deemed to be pending for the earlier years, the assessee's declaration made during the assessment proceedings for the year 1958-59 should be taken into account for the purpose of reassessments.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected assessee's submissions.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax officer rejected all the submissions.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee went up in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held ITO wrong; declaration applicable; sufficient cause for not filing earlier; no reduction in tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the income-tax officer's reasoning for not accepting the declaration under section 17(1) was not correct. ... the assessee had sufficient cause for not filing the declaration under section 17(1) when the assessee became first assessable. It was also held that the failure to file the declaration had not resulted in a reduction of tax liability.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed declaration for the three years as reassessments made after March 24, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration filed on March 24, 1959 by the assessee, in the opinion of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, could be availed of for the assessments for the three years in question as the assessment orders consequent upon the reopening of assessments were being made subsequent to that date.

facts.text: Department appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal; Tribunal accepted AAC reasoning and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The department went up in appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The Tribunal accepted the reasoning of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax moved Tribunal to refer question to High Court; Tribunal referred the question.

anchor.surface_text: On being moved by the Commissioner of Income-tax the Tribunal referred the question reproduced above to the High Court.

facts.text: Madras High Court answered question against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in answering the question against the assessee referred to the expression all assessments thereafter in the two provisos to section 17(1) of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, set aside High Court judgment, answered question in affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, accept these appeals, set aside the judgment of the High Court and discharge the answer given by it to the question referred to it. The question reproduced above is answered in the affirmative in favour of the assessee-appellant and against the revenue.

facts.text: Assessee entitled to costs in Supreme Court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appellant shall be entitled to his costs both in this Court as well as in the High Court.
under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 hereinafter referred

holdings.text: The question reproduced above is answered in the affirmative in favour of the assessee-appellant and against the revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The question reproduced above is answered in, the affirmative in favour of the assessee- appellant and against the revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second proviso to s.17(1) applies to reassessments made after declaration; 'all assessments thereafter' includes prior year reassessments; 'assessment' comprehensively includes reassessment; natural meaning, harmonious construction, avoids anomaly, supported by precedents and statutory context.

holdings.text: The words all assessments thereafter, in our opinion, signify not only assessments for the subsequent years but would also cover assessments for the earlier years in case the assessments for those earlier years are being made subsequent to the filing of the declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The words all assessments thereafter, in our opinion, signify not only assessments for. the subsequent years but would also cover assessments for the earlier years in case the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide amplitude and natural meaning given to phrase without restriction; covers all post-declaration assessments including prior year reassessments.

holdings.text: we see no cogent reason for not giving them their natural meaning or for restricting their scope.

anchor.surface_text: The wordsall assessments, thereafter have a wide amplitude and we see no cogent reason for not giving them their natural meaning or for restricting their scope. Those words

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain statutory language interpreted naturally absent compelling reason to limit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow interpretation limiting to original assessments; adopts comprehensive view including s.34 reassessments based on statutory scheme and precedents.

holdings.text: the word assessment in the second proviso to section 17(1) of the Act must necessarily, in our opinion, cover reassessment under section 34 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive sense of 'assessment' includes reassessment per 1961 Act s.2(8), precedents like Shenoy, and context; legislature distinguishes when intended (s.33B, s.67).

holdings.text: To hold otherwise would result in an anomalous situation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow view would absurdly apply declaration to escaped income but not under-assessments under s.34 contingencies.

holdings.text: The entire scheme of section 17(1) as well as the context, in our opinion, clearly shows that the word assessment in section 17(1) has been used in a comprehensive sense so as to include reassessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme and context demand inclusive meaning for 'assessment'.

precedents.citation: A. N. Lakshman Shenoy v. Income-tax Officer, Bangalore Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: A. N. Lakshman Shenoy v. Income-tax Officer, Bangalore Ors.  1  this Court held that the word assessment in-the Finance Act, 1950 would include reassessment. It was observed that the company- location of the words levy, assessment and companylection of income-tax showed that the word assessment had a companyprehensive meaning so as to companyr reassessment.

precedents.case_name: A. N. Lakshman Shenoy v. Income-tax Officer, Bangalore
precedents.cited_proposition: the word assessment in the Finance Act, 1950 would include reassessment
precedents.cited_holding: the word assessment had a comprehensive meaning so as to cover reassessment

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax.v. Khemchand Ramdas 2  upon which reliance had been placed by the,revenue in Shenoys case, as has also been done in the present case, was distinguished. This Court referred to the observations of the Judicial Committee in the case of Khemchand Ramdas and held that those, observations lend numbersupport to the view that the word assessment must always bear a particular meaning in the Income-tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Khemchand Ramdas
precedents.cited_proposition: observations on the meaning of assessment
precedents.cited_holding: using the word assessment in its comprehensive sense as including the whole procedure for imposing liability upon the taxpayer

precedents.citation: Commissioner for General. Purposes of Income Tax for the City of London v. Gibbs and Others 1

precedents.case_name: Commissioner for General Purposes of Income Tax for the City of London v. Gibbs and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: the word assessment is used in more than one sense
precedents.cited_holding: One, meaning is the fixing of the sum taken to represent the actual profit and the other the actual sum in tax which the taxpayer is liable to pay
